awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Research Experiences in Cybersecurity for Nevada Teachers (RECNT)
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding renews a Research Experience for Teachers (RET) Site at the University of Nevada, Reno (UNR). The primary objective of this RET Site is to explore unique ways to engage middle and high school teachers in summer research experiences that emphasize cybersecurity. Cybersecurity is an area of national importance that impacts the lives of all citizens.  The teachers will spend six weeks in the summer participating in research experiences and developing classroom modules and materials which will be implemented in their classrooms during the academic year. The project involves a partnership between the university, the school districts in the surrounding Nevada counties, and local industries. The project will develop a community of teachers who are passionate about cybersecurity and who can translate this excitement to their students through engaging, high-quality inquiry learning experiences.  This RET Site is co-funded by the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program.  

The project is anchored by a research area that is compelling and exciting for teachers and K-12 students and by a faculty team that has demonstrated expertise in both research and education.  The goals of the project are to: recruit a cohort of middle and high school teachers interested in introducing cybersecurity and computer science topics into their classrooms; engage the recruited teachers in research experiences with applications in various modern day systems and security; develop instructional modules that can be incorporated into a variety of classes; promote and disseminate the results to a large group of middle and high school teachers; and sustain long term partnerships between the RET Site teacher participants, the UNR mentor team and the university to bring the excitement of computing, problem solving and research to students and encourage them to pursue science, technology, engineering and math (STEM)-related careers. The site features projects that are teacher accessible as well as connected to current research and practice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SITE-Res Exp for Tchr Site
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project, "RET Site: Research Experiences in Cybersecurity for Nevada Teachers (RECNT)", explored unique ways to engage Middle and High School (MsHs) teacher participants in STEM education in research areas that were of "high state and national priority" and to sustain long-term research and education partnerships between participants, faculty and industry partners. The intellectual focus of RECNT had been research in computer science and engineering (CSE) fields with particular emphasis on cybersecurity.

The objectives were to: (1) attract and recruit a cohort of middle and high school (Ms/Hs) teachers interested in introducing computer science curriculum and cybersecurity issues and awareness into their courses; (2) engage the recruited teachers in CSE research principles with applications in various modern-day systems and security; (3) develop instructional modules that can be incorporated in a variety of grades/classes; (4) initiate collaboration and engagement with all schools in Nevada and other stakeholders in the country to promote and disseminate the results to a large group of MsHs teachers; and (5) sustain long term partnerships between teacher participants, UNR mentor team and industry partners, in order to help bring the excitement of computing, problem solving and research to a large segment of students and encourage them to pursue STEM related careers.

With the help of this RET Site in Nevada, the participants (1) have been exposed to the theory and application of CSE research with a focus on cybersecurity; (2) received background, materials and tools appropriate to active research projects of the mentors; (3) developed replicable teaching modules; (4) enabled other Nevada teachers and students to experience research ideas and practices; and (5) infused students with the desire to learn more and pursue STEM related careers.

The project has helped the UNR RET program and the teacher participants, and it has been able to help the students, the schools, the school districts, and state administrators in understanding the significance of cybersecurity research and education from the early stage.

The participants received ample exposure to the cybersecurity issues, concepts, risks, mitigation techniques, privacy, digital forensics, hands-on system development on state-of-the-art research laboratory equipment. The teachers participated in developing classroom modules taking experience from this site and they have started the process from early days of the site. Thousands of students are now getting exposed to cybersecurity awareness from their middle and high school due to the impact of this RET site. The RET website is now fully functional as part of the site activity: https://recnt.cse.unr.edu/. Many of the schools have started their own student clubs inspired by UNR cyber club and started taking part in cyber league and capture-the-flag style competitions. The teachers taking part in RET site activities have led their way for the school clubs.

Relevant subjects taught by the participating teachers included: Computer Science & Applications, Cybersecurity I, Cybersecurity II, and Cybersecurity III Honors, & Science Independent Studies, PLTW Environmental Sustainability, STEAM: Green Architecture, Military Science, Programming, AP Computer Science Principles, IT essentials etc.

The project has enabled us to develop new cybersecurity programs such as Cybersecurity Graduate Certificate and Cybersecurity Master's program at University of Nevada, Reno and making the UNR Cybersecurity Center a nationwide prominent Center.


Last Modified: 10/23/2023
Modified by: Shamik Sengupta
